## Context

> tl;dr
>
> We have workspaces within the project but no official way of connecting them or managing dependencies from the top-level. Similarly, scripts that grow in size or complexity have no dedicated home or ability to manage dependencies outside of the top-level workspace.

The `primer/react` repo is composed of several workspaces that use `npm` to manage dependencies. In order to install these dependencies, a contributor needs to visit each directory and run `npm install`. The project also has a convenience script for this task, invoked through `npm run setup`, that goes through this process for contributors.

These distinct workspaces may sometimes depend on each other. For example, the `docs` workspace depends on the `@primer/react` package which is defined at the top-level of the project. Similarly, examples in the `examples/*` folders may also depend on `@primer/react`. Currently these dependencies are expressed either through relative paths, file dependencies in `package.json`, or symlinks through `npm link`.

There is also a collection of scripts under the `script` directory that exist in the project that involve varying levels of complexity and depth.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

Adopt a monorepo tool to manage workspaces, dependencies, and scripts holistically. Use `pnpm` with its built-in workspace support to unify dependency management across all packages.

Key decisions:
- Replace individual `npm install` calls in each workspace with a single, top-level `pnpm install` that manages all dependencies across workspaces.
- Define inter-package dependencies using version ranges (e.g., `workspace:*`) so that local packages are automatically linked during development and resolved correctly in CI/publishing.
- Migrate all existing workspaces to be part of the `pnpm` workspace configuration via `packages` field in `pnpm-workspace.yaml`.
- Move and modularize scripts under the `scripts/` directory into standalone workspace(s), such as `@primer/scripts`, allowing them to have their own dependencies and executable binaries.
- Update the `setup` script to run `pnpm install` at the root, ensuring consistent and reproducible installations.

This approach eliminates manual linking, simplifies onboarding, ensures consistent dependency resolution, and provides a scalable structure for growing tooling. Additionally, `pnpm`’s high performance and symlink-free linking make it well-suited for our monorepo needs.

## Context

Reasons for change: Performance, utilise css variables

The main reason for changing our styling architecture is to remove performance issues for applications:

Relevant parts from [primer/discussions#1928](https://github.com/github/primer/discussions/1928#reasons)(Hubbers only link):

1. Initial page loads take longer

   Because styles are injected during runtime, we can not parallelize this work. The page is un-styled till the javascript bundle is
   downloaded and processed. The processing time is longer on slower devices.

   Benchmarks:

   i. Lab benchmarks: rendering a page with 1000 components
   runtime injection of css: 242ms
   static .css files: 96ms (60% faster)

   ii. Application benchmarks: render times for repo directory (>1000 files, [gh/gh#241090](https://github.com/github/github/pull/241090))
   with primer/react Box: 3800ms
   with custom css: 3076ms (20% faster)

2. Slow server side rendering

   Some applications are able to make up for slower initial render times by collecting styles on the server first. In the correct stack, collecting styles requires rendering the app twice before we can ship any html to the user.

   benchmarks: in the issues-app experiment, collecting styles on the server contributed to + 20% of rendering time (450ms on top of 1900ms)

3. Style updates are expensive

   The slowest part of the current stack is updating styles based on props or state. Big changes take linearly longer, worse on slower devices.

   Benchmarks:

   i. Lab benchmarks: updating a page with 1000 components, static runtime css vs. dynamic runtime css (thanks @mattcosta7 for these!)

   re-rendering components with fixed styles on runtime: 242ms
   re-rendering components with dynamic styles on runtime: 441ms (55% slower)

   ii. Application benchmarks: opting out of IconButton for PR diff view (>500 files, [gh/gh#243269](https://github.com/github/github/pull/243269))

   dynamic styles with sx prop: 400ms
   dynamic styles with .css files: 165ms (60% faster)

The other reasons for change are to utilise css variables for theming and improve the guardrails of consuming primer/primitives
decision:
## Decision  
## Decision

Migrate from runtime style injection (e.g., `@primer/react`'s `sx` prop) to static CSS files using CSS Custom Properties (CSS variables) for styling.

### Key Decisions:

- **Adopt static `.css` or `.css.ts` files** for component styles to enable:
  - Parallel downloading of CSS and JavaScript.
  - Faster initial render by eliminating the need to inject styles at runtime.
  - Improved server-side rendering performance by removing double-rendering requirements for style collection.

- **Use CSS Custom Properties (variables)** to support dynamic theming capabilities previously provided by the `sx` prop, enabling:
  - Runtime theme switching without re-rendering.
  - Consistent and scalable theming across applications.
  - Better alignment with Primer Primitives and design tokens.

- **Define strict style composition patterns** to improve developer guardrails and prevent unsafe overrides, including:
  - Discouraging unrestricted inline styles or ad-hoc `sx` usage.
  - Encouraging use of predefined utility classes and token-driven values.

- **Update build tooling** to support:
  - Extraction and bundling of static CSS.
  - Inclusion of CSS variables in design system deliverables.
  - Tree-shaking unused styles where possible.

This shift improves runtime performance, reduces JavaScript overhead, accelerates page loads, and maintains flexibility for theming and customization — aligning with modern best practices for scalable, high-performance web applications.

## Context

There are situations where a component prop can support a value or a "responsive
value" that results in the value changing depending on the viewport size. For
example:

```tsx
// Value
<Stack gap="condensed" />

// Responsive value
<Stack gap={{ narrow: 'condensed', regular: 'normal', wide: 'spacious' />
```

Typically, a responsive value will support all of our named breakpoints: narrow,
regular, and wide. Authors can use a hook called `useResponsiveValue` to support
resolving the value of a prop based on the current viewport size. The
implementation of this hook uses [`matchMedia`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/matchMedia)
which, unfortunately, has a downside: the value of a prop may shift when the
component is server-side rendered. If the prop is used for styles or layout, then this will lead to a layout shift
when the component hydrates and the viewport size is different than the fallback
size on the server.

As a result, we would like to offer a paved path for providing responsive props
in a way tha twill not lead to layout shift during server-side rendering.

## Context

There are times when a prop is deprecated in favor of a more accessible API or a more flexible prop that can support a wider range of values. In these cases, we want to provide a clear path for authors to migrate from the deprecated prop to the new API.

For
example:

```tsx
// old API
<ActionList>
  <ActionList.Group title="Group title">
    <ActionList.Item>Item 1</ActionList.Item>
    <ActionList.Item>Item 2</ActionList.Item>
  </ActionList.Group>
</ActionList>
```

```tsx
// new API
<ActionList>
  <ActionList.Group>
    <ActionList.GroupHeading as="h2">Group title</ActionList.GroupHeading>
    <ActionList.Item>Item 1</ActionList.Item>
    <ActionList.Item>Item 2</ActionList.Item>
  </ActionList.Group>
</ActionList>
```
decision:
## Decision  
## Decision

We will deprecate the `title` prop in `ActionList.Group` in favor of the new, more accessible and semantically correct `ActionList.GroupHeading` component. This change allows authors to:

- Control the heading level via the `as` prop (e.g., `h2`, `h3`), improving document structure and accessibility.
- Use richer content within group headings if needed (e.g., icons, emphasis).
- Align with modern UI component design principles that separate structure from content.

### Migration Path
1. **Deprecation**: The `title` prop is marked as deprecated in TypeScript and documented as such in the component API.
2. **Warning**: A runtime warning is logged in development mode when the `title` prop is used, directing developers to use `ActionList.GroupHeading`.
3. **Documentation**: The docs are updated to showcase the new pattern as the recommended approach, with a clear deprecation notice for the old API.
4. **Removal**: The `title` prop will be removed in the next major version.

### Example Update
```tsx
// Before
<ActionList.Group title="Group title">
  <ActionList.Item>Item 1</ActionList.Item>
</ActionList.Group>

// After
<ActionList.Group>
  <ActionList.GroupHeading as="h2">Group title</ActionList.GroupHeading>
  <ActionList.Item>Item 1</ActionList.Item>
</ActionList.Group>
```

This change supports better accessibility, flexibility, and semantic markup while providing a smooth migration path.

## Context

- Proxy support is required for some enterprises and organizations to start using their own self-hosted runners
- While there is not a standard convention, many applications support setting proxies via the environment variables `http_proxy`, `https_proxy`, `no_proxy`, such as curl, wget, perl, python, docker, git, and R

decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will support proxy configuration through the standard environment variables `http_proxy`, `https_proxy`, and `no_proxy` using lowercase names. This aligns with common industry practice observed in tools such as curl, wget, git, Docker, and others. The proxy settings will be automatically detected and applied when making outbound HTTP/HTTPS requests from self-hosted runners.

Support for uppercase variants (`HTTP_PROXY`, `HTTPS_PROXY`, `NO_PROXY`) will also be implemented for backward compatibility and broader interoperability, but documentation will emphasize the lowercase forms as canonical. The `no_proxy` variable will support comma-separated hostnames, IP addresses, and domain suffixes to bypass the proxy where needed.

This approach ensures seamless integration into enterprise environments with existing proxy infrastructure without requiring additional configuration beyond standard environment setup.

## Decision

We will update the Runner to use the conventional environment variables for proxies: `http_proxy`, `https_proxy`, and `no_proxy` if they are set.
These are described in detail below:
- `https_proxy` a proxy URL for all https traffic. It may contain basic authentication credentials. For example:
  - http://proxy.com
  - http://127.0.0.1:8080
  - http://user:password@proxy.com
- `http_proxy` a proxy URL for all http traffic. It may contain basic authentication credentials. For example:
  - http://proxy.com
  - http://127.0.0.1:8080
  - http://user:password@proxy.com
- `no_proxy` a comma-separated list of hosts that should not use the proxy. An optional port may be specified. For example:
  - `google.com`
  - `yahoo.com:443`
  - `google.com,bing.com`

We won't use `http_proxy` for https traffic when `https_proxy` is not set, this behavior lines up with any libcurl based tools (curl, git) and wget.
Otherwise, action authors and workflow users need to adjust to differences between the runner proxy convention, and tools used by their actions and scripts.  

Example:  
  Customer sets `http_proxy=http://127.0.0.1:8888` and configures the runner against `https://github.com/owner/repo`, with the `https_proxy` -> `http_proxy` fallback, the runner will connect to the server without any problem. However, if a user runs `git push` to `https://github.com/owner/repo`, `git` won't use the proxy since it requires `https_proxy` to be set for any https traffic.

> `golang`, `node.js`, and other dev tools from the Linux community use `http_proxy` for both http and https traffic based on my research.

A majority of our users are using Linux where these variables are commonly required to be set by various programs. By reading these values, we simplify the process for self-hosted runners to set up a proxy and expose it in a way users are already familiar with.

A password provided for a proxy will be masked in the logs.

We will support the lowercase and uppercase variants, with lowercase taking priority if both are set.

## Context

Command echoing as a default behavior tends to clutter the user logs, so we want to swap to a system where users have to opt in to see this information.

Command outputs will still be echoed in the case there are any errors processing such commands. This is so the end user can have more context on why the command failed and help with troubleshooting.

Echo output in the user logs can be explicitly controlled by the new commands `::echo::on` and `::echo::off`. By default, echoing is enabled if `ACTIONS_STEP_DEBUG` secret is enabled, otherwise echoing is disabled.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

Change the default command echoing behavior to be disabled unless explicitly enabled.

Echoing of commands in logs will now follow this logic:
- By default, command echoing is **disabled** to reduce log clutter.
- Echoing is automatically **enabled** if the `ACTIONS_STEP_DEBUG` secret is set, allowing maintainers or advanced users to opt into verbose output.
- Users can explicitly control echoing within a workflow using the `::echo::on` and `::echo::off` commands for fine-grained control.
- Command echoing is **automatically re-enabled** when a command fails, ensuring error context is visible for debugging purposes.

This change improves log readability while preserving diagnostic capability when needed.

runs-on: [self-hosted, mylabel, anotherlabel]

## Context
SS?? fundamentally relies on a third-party provider service to authenticate requests (e.g. OAuth2
via Google). The provider may experience transient faults for any number of reasons - perhaps the
provider is experiencing a transient outage, or our traffic has been temporarily rate limited. We
wanted to build SS?? to anticipate and handle the presence of faults during communication with
authentication providers, no matter the underlying cause.
decision:
## Decision  
## Decision

We will implement a resilient authentication layer that gracefully handles transient faults when communicating with third-party identity providers. This includes:

* Introducing configurable retry mechanisms with exponential backoff for failed authentication requests.
* Wrapping external provider calls in a fault-tolerant abstraction (e.g., a dedicated auth client with built-in circuit breaker patterns).
* Ensuring authentication failures are logged meaningfully without exposing sensitive information.
* Returning user-friendly error messages to the client while preserving security guarantees.

This approach ensures that temporary outages or rate limiting on the provider side do not result in complete authentication failure, improving system reliability and user experience.
predicted_decision:
## Decision
We implemented a generic `circuit.Breaker` type, which implements the "Circuit Breaker" design
pattern made popular by Michael T. Nygard's book, ["Release It!"](
https://pragprog.com/book/mnee/release-it). All requests to the provider service are issued through
a stateful `circuit.Breaker` instance, which tracks the frequency of request failures. When the
`Breaker` sees that enough requests are failing, it temporarily suspends all outgoing traffic to the
provider (i.e. "enters `Open` state). After some time, the `Breaker` transitions to a `HalfOpen`
state, in which a limited number of outbound requests are allowed. If failures persist, then the
`Breaker` will once again suspend outbound traffic, re-enter `Open` state, and typically will wait
for a longer interval of time before trying again. If instead the `Breaker` observes that requests
are consistently succeeding, then it will resume all outbound traffic (i.e. enter `Closed` state).

The SS?? [`docs`](/docs/) directory contains a [Circuit Breaker](
/docs/architecture/circuit-breaker.md) document with more details. The implementation can be found
in [`breaker.go`](/internal/auth/circuit/breaker.go)

## Context

Extensions are defined by an EDN file accessed from decentralized storage. An URI schema allows to identify those files.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

The URI schema for extensions MUST follow the format: `extension://<namespace>/<name>`, where:

- `<namespace>` identifies the organization, project, or domain that owns the extension,
- `<name>` is the unique identifier of the extension within that namespace.

The EDN file located at the resolved decentralized storage address MUST contain:
- A `spec-version` field indicating compatibility with the extension system,
- A `dependencies` section listing any required extensions or runtime versions,
- A `handlers` map defining entrypoints for execution,
- A `metadata` section including human-readable name, description, and version.

Resolution of the URI is performed by:
1. Mapping the `extension://` scheme to a configured decentralized storage gateway (e.g., IPFS, Filecoin, Arweave),
2. Resolving `<namespace>/<name>` to a content ID (CID) via a registry contract or DNS-based lookup,
3. Fetching and validating the EDN file from the decentralized network.

Caching of resolved URIs and their contents is RECOMMENDED to improve performance and reduce network load.

context:
## Context

Currently peers for messaging are hardcoded in the app. This means we can't
easily scale, as some of these nodes might fill up when we have more than N
active users.

Discovery v5 protocol (https://ideas.status.im/ideas/092-disc-v5-research,
https://github.com/fjl/p2p-drafts/blob/master/discv5-eip.md) allow us to
discover new peers from the app and scale server peers in our cluster
independently. This is vital for high availability/reliability and security.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will implement Discovery v5 protocol to enable dynamic peer discovery and improve scalability, reliability, and security of our messaging infrastructure.

Hardcoded peer configurations are not sustainable for growing user bases and introduce single points of failure. By adopting Discovery v5, we allow clients to dynamically discover available and healthy peers in the network without requiring configuration changes or app updates.

Key benefits include:

- **Scalability**: Server peers can be added or removed independently of client deployments.
- **High Availability**: Clients can automatically discover alternative peers if some nodes become unreachable.
- **Decentralized Operations**: Reduces dependency on centralized peer lists, aligning with decentralized architecture principles.
- **Security**: Supports encrypted handshake and topic-based node discovery, improving resistance to spoofing and eavesdropping.

Implementation steps:
1. Integrate Discovery v5 library (e.g., `discv5` in Go or equivalent).
2. Configure bootstrap nodes to seed initial network connectivity.
3. Set up topic-based discovery for specific services or regions if needed.
4. Deprecate hardcoded peer lists and migrate existing peers into the discoverable network.
5. Monitor peer health and discovery performance via observability tools.

This decision aligns with long-term goals of building a resilient, scalable, and maintainable peer-to-peer messaging system.

## Context

Idea [142-Wallet-Compatibility](https://ideas.status.im/ideas/142-wallet-compatibility/README) changes the way we generate keys starting from the 12 mnemonic words.

This change allows users to create a wallet in other apps and import the same address in Status using the 12 mnemonic words.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We adopt BIP-39 (mnemonic phrase) and BIP-44 (multi-account hierarchy) standards for key derivation in Status Wallet to ensure cross-wallet compatibility.

This decision aligns with the broader ecosystem by using industry-standard deterministic key generation, enabling users to recover their Status wallet accounts in other compliant wallets (e.g., Ledger, MetaMask, Trust Wallet) using the same 12-word mnemonic seed, and vice versa.

Key changes include:

- **Mnemonic Generation**: Use BIP-39 to generate a cryptographically secure 12-word mnemonic from entropy.
- **Key Derivation**: Use BIP-44 derivation path `m/44'/60'/0'/0/0` for Ethereum-compatible accounts (adjustable per coin type as needed).
- **Wallet Import/Export**: Support importing and exporting wallets via the 12-word mnemonic, ensuring interoperability.
- **User Experience**: Maintain a simple onboarding flow where users back up their mnemonic during wallet creation.

Backward compatibility will be preserved by allowing existing account types to continue functioning, while new wallets default to the BIP-39/BIP-44 standard.

Security considerations:
- Users are educated on the critical importance of securing their mnemonic.
- No plaintext storage of mnemonics in app state; encrypted storage only where necessary.
- Warnings are displayed during backup and restore flows.

This change significantly improves user experience and trust by eliminating vendor lock-in and adhering to widely reviewed and adopted standards.

context:
## Context

On the path to releasing a usable beta we've faced a variety of performance
issues:

- https://github.com/status-im/ideas/issues/55
- https://ideas.status.im/ideas/071-low-traffic
- https://ideas.status.im/ideas/076-smooth-ui
- https://ideas.status.im/ideas/083-energy-efficient

Some of these performance issues are related to the use of LES, especially on
Mainnet. Examples of problems include: slow/hot sync, disk filling up, bandwidth
usage, etc. This can partly be remedied by the use of CHT to speed up sync
(https://github.com/status-im/status-go/wiki/Updating-CHT-BloomTrie).

In order to simplify the problem, we decided earlier this year to not spend too
much time looking into performance improvements related to LES, instead focusing
our efforts on improving the performance on Whisper and in client-side code.

This also means we don't have a full picture of to what extent LES is a
performance bottleneck for the Status app. It is possible proper use of CHT,
slowing sync down, vary load depending on if you are on WiFi or not, etc, can
solve these problems. However, the consensus right now is that ULC is the more
promising route to take.

However, since ULC isn't ready yet, this means we are relying on Infura. This
is a bad idea from a decentralization and security point of view. This can be
partly remedied by allowing the user to run an upstream node. It is still a bad
trust model, relying on third-party Ethereum nodes, and we want to get away
from this as soon as possible.

With ULC it is possible to connect to more than one node, which increases
decentralization and security.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will proceed with the development and integration of Ultra-Light Client (ULC) as the primary path forward for improving Ethereum node performance and reducing reliance on centralized infrastructure like Infura.

Given the known limitations of LES—particularly its impact on sync speed, disk usage, bandwidth consumption, and overall device performance—and the current lack of a comprehensive performance optimization strategy for LES in resource-constrained environments, ULC presents a more sustainable and secure alternative.

ULC enables trust-minimized connectivity to multiple upstream nodes, improving both decentralization and resilience compared to relying on a single third-party node. While ULC is not yet production-ready, we will prioritize its completion and testing to enable a beta release that maintains acceptable performance without compromising core decentralized principles.

In the interim, we will continue using Infura with the option for users to configure a custom upstream node, but this will be treated as a temporary mitigation. No significant engineering effort will be invested in optimizing LES beyond critical bug fixes or minimal CHT-related improvements that are low-risk and easy to maintain.

The focus of performance work will remain on client-side optimizations and Whisper improvements, while laying the groundwork for a full transition to ULC upon its readiness.

We have some data that we don't want to appear in the logs (user passwords are
a good example). Currently, they are passed around as strings, that could be

## Decision 
## Decision

We introduce a new type `Secp256k1` to represent private keys and sensitive data such as passwords. This type ensures that sensitive values are not accidentally logged or exposed in plaintext by overriding the default string representation.

The `Secp256k1` type (or an equivalent `SecretString`/`RedactedString` type, depending on context) should:

- Wrap the sensitive string value.
- Implement interfaces such as `fmt.Stringer` to return a redacted placeholder (e.g., `"<redacted>"`) when converted to a string.
- Provide controlled methods (e.g., `.Expose()`) for accessing the underlying value only in secure, intentional contexts.
- Be used consistently across the codebase for all sensitive inputs like passwords, mnemonics, and private keys.

This prevents accidental leakage via logs, error messages, or debug output while maintaining usability where the actual value is required (e.g., during cryptographic operations).

context:
## Context

Originally, we supported 3rd party status extensions in form of javascript jailed execution environment (eq Jail) + small js library exposing chat commands API to js code.

While neat in theory, it has some serious downsides:

- Design of the API was quite poor, preferring mutable semantics over stateless API leveraging strength of the host application (cljs/re-frame).
  As a result of that, more dynamic/state requiring things (like the live tx detail in `/send` command messages) were very hard to do,
  so instead of "eating our own dogfood", we decided to side-step the API and implement such things as hard-coded logic in the app, while partly
  retaining the js code for "easier" things (like parameter declaration).
  Needles to say, such efforts produced code of very poor quality, riddling our app with hard-coded "magic" everywhere in the codebase, completely
  defeating the point of "dogfooding" while still requiring more effort and being much more error prone (no way to unit test jail logic) because 
  of the need to asynchronously communicate with jail for leftover logic in command messages (the parts not hardcoded in app).
  
- We were in a state where there was not even one command defined completely in jail, with all of them requiring custom hardcoded logic in app to
  actually work.
  Due to numerous changes and rush to get things working, half of the API was obsolete and was not working/working differently then described in
  the API documentation.
  
- We are quite tight stretched regarding performance and the Jail didn't particularly help with that - whenever some command message was defined in
  Jail, it required constant RN Bridge "ping-pong" whenever sending the message or receiving the message, eating more resources + breaking otherwise
  quite simple logic into harder to reason asynchronous call chains (execute method defined in Jail, wait for the result, execute next method in Jail...).
  
- Till now, there was no real interest in 3rd party bots anyway - the only "real" DAPPs submitted to status were "normal" DAPPs utilising just the `web3.js`
  API and built on top of regular web technologies, so they could be ran in any Ethereum client like Metamask or Mist, besides Status.
  
- There is a very promising new concept of extensions (project pluto), which will enable to extend status with much nicer and declarative extension
  definitions.
  Such extensions will not be able to only hook-in into the command messages logic, but also other application (host) hooks, like wallet assets/collectibles,
  chat contacts, etc.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

Given the above context and the numerous shortcomings of the existing JavaScript Jail (Jail) system, we have decided to **deprecate and remove support for 3rd party status extensions based on the Jail execution environment**.

This decision is based on the following key factors:

- The current API design encourages poor engineering practices, leads to tightly coupled and hard-to-maintain code, and undermines our ability to "eat our own dogfood" by forcing critical functionality into app-side hardcoded logic.
- No command is fully implemented in Jail — all rely on fragile, synchronous workarounds that increase complexity and reduce testability.
- Performance is negatively impacted due to constant asynchronous communication across the React Native bridge, which harms user experience and increases memory and CPU usage.
- There has been no real-world adoption of Jail-based 3rd party bots or extensions; existing DApps function perfectly using standard web3.js and web-based tooling.
- A superior alternative is on the horizon with **Project Pluto**, which promises a declarative, secure, and deeply integrated extension model that supports not only chat commands but also wallet, contact, and UI integrations in a maintainable and performant way.

As part of this decision:
- We will **cease development and maintenance** of the Jail-based extension API.
- Existing Jail-dependent features will be **migrated to native implementations** or re-implemented using future Pluto-compatible patterns.
- Future extensibility efforts will focus exclusively on **Project Pluto** and its architecture.

This paves the way for a cleaner, more maintainable codebase and aligns our platform with modern, scalable extension models.

## Context

The whitepaper describes Tribute to Talk (TtT) as an economics-based anti-spam filter for receiving messages and "cold" contact requests from user. Stakeholders would stake a minimum amount of SNT that another Status stakeholder must deposit in order to contact him directly.
The whitepaper also proposes that the deposit is only forfeited to the recipient if he replies.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will implement Tribute to Talk (TtT) as a module that enables users to set a staking requirement for receiving direct messages or contact requests. This mechanism acts as an economics-based anti-spam filter.

Key design decisions:

- Users can configure a minimum amount of SNT (or another designated token) that must be deposited by any sender wishing to initiate a direct message or "cold" contact request.
- The deposit is held in escrow when the message/request is sent.
- The deposit is only transferred to the recipient if they choose to reply, serving as both compensation and incentive alignment.
- If the recipient does not reply within a defined time window, the deposit is refunded to the sender.
- Users can disable TtT or set the required stake to zero to allow free communication.
- The module integrates with the existing `x/bank` and `x/staking` modules for token transfers and balance checks.
- Deposit parameters (minimum amount, timeout duration) are configurable per user and enforceable through protobuf messages authenticated via the standard Cosmos SDK signing mechanism.

This implementation aligns with the original whitepaper vision while ensuring compatibility with the modular architecture of the Cosmos SDK.
predicted_decision:
## Decision

Considering:
- the absence of efficient ways to perform anonymous transactions (zk-snarks could be used in the future for that)
- the impossibility to prove that a recipient has made an actual reply and not some kind of automated reply (captcha solution was proposed, but wouldn't be practical until we can use a solution such as swarm feeds that allow users to make free updates to their captcha without on-chain transactions)
- the limited time to develop the feature

We opted for a solution that:
- doesn't establish a direct correlation between the tribute payment and an on-chain transaction, so it
- uses regular transactions for tributes payment, giving users plausible deniability about the nature of the payment
- doesn't store tribute information on-chain

## Context

During the development of a new Sylius API (based on API Platform) for Product Options, we had to decide how we should handle
Product Option's values collection, to make it efficient and easy to use.
decision:
## Decision  
## Decision Outcome

We will model Product Option values as a dedicated resource in the Sylius API, embedded within the Product entity via API Platform’s nested subresources and attribute serialization groups.

This approach ensures:

- **Efficiency**: Values are only loaded when explicitly requested, avoiding unnecessary data fetching.
- **Consistency**: Aligns with API Platform best practices and Sylius's resource-oriented architecture.
- **Usability**: Enables clear endpoints such as `GET /api/v2/products/{id}/options` and supports filtering, pagination, and sorting where applicable.
- **Flexibility**: Supports future extensions like per-channel option value pricing or translations.

We use API Platform’s `subresourceOperations` to expose option values under their parent product, and leverage serialization groups (`product:read`, `product_option:read`) to control payload size and structure.

This decision avoids denormalizing option values into the main Product response, which would increase payload size and complexity, especially for products with many variants and options.

## Context and Problem Statement

A big chunk of resources available in Sylius have some part locale aware. Product descriptions, names of payment or shipping methods
should be translated to the customer to provide the best user experience. Right now most of the resources are returned with 
all available translations in the store and proper localization of content is left to the frontend developers. What is more,
this solution is not consistent, as some endpoints already embeds some part of translatables in them. We should provide clear,
easy to use and consistent way of handling customer locales.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will standardize the handling of locale-aware resources in Sylius by adopting a request-driven localization approach. The API will return content localized to the requested locale, based on an explicit `Accept-Language` header or a provided locale parameter.

If no locale is specified, the store’s default locale will be used. Translations not available in the requested locale will fall back according to the locale fallback chain (e.g., `fr-CA` → `fr` → default locale).

All endpoints must:
- Accept an optional locale context via `Accept-Language` header or query parameter.
- Return only the relevant translation for the requested locale within the main resource payload.
- Omit untranslated fields only if they are required; otherwise, they may be null or excluded based on configuration.
- Avoid returning full translation arrays unless explicitly requested (e.g., via an `include=translations` parameter).

This ensures consistency across endpoints, reduces payload size, and shifts the responsibility of localization from frontend developers to the API layer, improving usability and user experience.

Decisions that affect the development of Terraform Controller that are not
captured via a proposal need to be captured in some way. We need a method that
is lightweight and easy to discover the decision that have been made. The record

decision:
## Decision  
## Decision

We will use lightweight Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) to document decisions related to the Terraform Controller that are not captured via formal proposals. These ADRs will be stored in a dedicated `docs/adr` directory in the project repository in Markdown format.

Each ADR will follow a simplified version of the Michael Nygard template, including:

- **Title** – a short descriptive name
- **Status** – e.g., proposed, accepted, rejected, deprecated
- **Context** – the problem or situation that prompted the decision
- **Decision** – the chosen solution or action
- **Date** – when the decision was made
- **Consequences** – implications, both positive and negative

This approach is lightweight, version-controlled, and easily discoverable through the codebase. It integrates naturally with pull requests and code reviews, ensuring transparency and traceability without introducing process overhead. Future contributors can quickly understand the rationale behind key implementation choices.

context:
## Context

Like [Flux](https://fluxcd.io/), the tf-controller API has a handful
of places where it accepts cross-namespace references.

 - `Terraform.spec.sourceRef` -- refers to the Flux source object with
   the Terraform program
 - `Terraform.spec.dependsOn[]` -- refers to other objects that must
   be ready before this object can be run
 - `.data.resources[]` -- in the config struct used by the branch
   planner

In general in Kubernetes, references to objects in other namespaces
are frowned upon, because

 - they break namespace isolation assurances; and,
 - they encourage the proliferation of permissions.

Both of these effects make a system less secure.

However: removing cross-namespace refs entirely would break some
installations in a way that would be difficult to fix, because Flux
deployments often rely on defining sources away from objects that use
them.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will allow cross-namespace references in the tf-controller API, but with explicit opt-in via a new `namespace` field in reference types, and enforce strict permission controls to mitigate security risks.

For each cross-namespace reference (e.g., `Terraform.spec.sourceRef`, `Terraform.spec.dependsOn[]`, and `.data.resources[]`), we will:

1. **Require explicit namespace qualification**: References to objects in other namespaces must include the `namespace` field. Omitting it implies the reference is within the same namespace (default behavior).

2. **Enforce RBAC at admission control**: The controller will verify that the service account managing the referencing object has appropriate cross-namespace permissions (e.g., `get` on the referenced resource type in the target namespace) before allowing the reference.

3. **Log and audit cross-namespace references**: All cross-namespace references will be logged to aid in security auditing and troubleshooting.

4. **Document security implications**: Clear documentation will warn users about the security trade-offs of using cross-namespace references and recommend colocation of resources when possible.

This approach preserves backward compatibility and supports existing workflows while improving safety and transparency around cross-namespace dependencies.
predicted_decision:
## Decision

Deny cross-namespace references by default, but allow them to be
enabled with a flag.

So that the default value means the right thing, the flag name must be
`enable-cross-namespace-refs`, and the default `false`. To avoid
confusion when people try to use the Flux version of this flag
`--disable-cross-namespace-refs`, it should be supported too, but only
respected if supplied.

context:
## Context

The TF-Controller currently faces challenges related to the deletion of Terraform resources.
These problems span across three categories:

1. Single object deletion,
2. Resources with dependencies deletion, and
3. Namespace deletion.

These problems must be fixed in the above order as (2) and (3) require single object deletion to be resolved first.

Deleting a single TF object can sometimes be obstructed because it's tied to other resources like Source objects, Secrets, and ConfigMaps. If we try to remove it without deleting these resources, the TF object gets stuck in an inconsistent state, making it harder for users to manage their infrastructure smoothly.
Therefore, the TF-Controller is being enhanced to address this problem more efficiently, using the contents of generated Workspace BLOBs. Each BLOB contains all necessary information from the associated Source, Secrets, and ConfigMaps to ensure that TF-Controller finalization procedures can delete objects correctly.

Currently, the TF-Controller downloads a Source BLOB and pushes it to a tf-runner. The tf-runner processes this BLOB to create a Workspace file system. It generates a backend configuration file, variable files, and other necessary files for the Workspace file system, using data from associated Secrets and ConfigMaps. This newly created Workspace file system is then compressed, sent back to the TF-Controller, and stored as a Workspace BLOB in the controller's storage.
A caching mechanism for these BLOBs is essential to fixing the single TF object deletion process.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will implement a caching mechanism for Workspace BLOBs in the TF-Controller to enable reliable deletion of single Terraform objects.

The cache will store the most recent version of each Workspace BLOB, preserving all information required to reconstruct the associated infrastructure state, including configurations derived from Source objects, Secrets, and ConfigMaps. This cached BLOB will be retained until finalization is complete.

During deletion, if a Terraform object is blocked due to dependencies, the TF-Controller will retrieve the corresponding Workspace BLOB from the cache. Using the embedded configuration data, the controller (or an accompanying tf-runner) will perform a targeted `terraform destroy` operation scoped precisely to the resources managed by that object. This ensures dependent resources (e.g., cloud instances, networks, buckets) are cleanly removed before Kubernetes-level garbage collection proceeds.

The caching mechanism will:
- Be keyed by Terraform object identifier (namespace/name).
- Persist BLOBs through restarts using durable storage (e.g., persistent volume or object store).
- Enforce a TTL or size-based eviction policy to prevent unbounded growth.
- Be cleaned up automatically upon successful deletion finalization.

This approach decouples deletion logic from live dependency references and allows the TF-Controller to act autonomously during cleanup, significantly improving reliability and user experience. It also lays the foundation for handling dependent and namespace-scoped deletions in future iterations.
predicted_decision:
## Decision

1. **BLOB Creation and Storage**
   * A gRPC function named `CreateWorkspaceBlob` will be invoked by the TF-Controller 
     to tell tf-runner to compress the Workspace file system into a tar.gz BLOB, which is then retrieved back to the controller.
   * The caching mechanism will be executed right before the Terraform Initialization step, ensuring that the latest and most relevant data is used.
   * Each Workspace Blob will be cached on the TF-Controller's local disk, using the UUID of the Terraform object as the filename,`${uuid}.tar.gz`.
   * To reduce the risk of unauthorized access to the cache entries, and cache collisions, the cache file will be deleted after the finalization process is complete.
2. **Persistence** 
   * [The persistence mechanism used by the Source Controller](https://fluxcd.io/flux/installation/configuration/vertical-scaling/#persistent-storage-for-flux-internal-artifacts) will be adopted for the TF-Controller's persistence volume.
3. **BLOB Encryption**
   * The encryption and decryption of the BLOBs will be tasked to the runner, with the controller solely responsible for storing encrypted BLOBs.
   * Each namespace will require a service account, preferably named "tf-runner".
   * The token of this service account, which is natively supported by Kubernetes, will serve as the most appropriate encryption key because it's stored in a Secret, access to which can be controlled by RBAC. Storing it in a Secret also allows the key to be rotated.
4. **Security Measures (Based on STRIDE Analysis)**
   * **Spoofing:** Implement Kubernetes RBAC for access restrictions and use mutual authentication for gRPC communications.
   * **Tampering:** Use checksums for integrity verification and 0600 permissions to write-protect local disk storage.
   * **Repudiation:** Ensure strong logging and auditing mechanisms for tracking activities.
   * **Information Disclosure:** Utilize robust encryption algorithms, rotate encryption keys periodically, and secure service account tokens.
   * **Denial of Service:** Monitor storage space and automate cleanup processes.
   * **Elevation of Privilege:** Minimize permissions associated with service account tokens.
5. **First MVP & Future Planning**
   * For the initial MVP, the default pod local volume will be used.
   * Since a controller restart will erase the BLOB cache, consideration for using persistent volumes should be made for subsequent versions.

context:
## Context

In previous releases of Zarf, the creation of the initialization package at the core of many of our E2E tests required repository secrets to login to registry1. Since this is an open-source project, anyone could submit a change to one of our GitHub workflows that could steal our secrets. In order to protect our secrets from any bad-actors we used [peter-evans/slash-command-dispatch@v2](https://github.com/peter-evans/slash-command-dispatch) so that only a maintainer would have the ability to run the E2E tests when a PR is submitted for review.

In the current version of Zarf (v0.15) images from registry1 are no longer needed to create the zarf-init-{{arch}}.tar.zst. This means, given our current span of E2E tests, we no longer need to use repository secrets when running tests. This gives us the ability to reassess the way we do our E2E testing.

When considering how to handle the tests, some of the important additions we were considering were:
  1. Ability to test against different kubernetes distributions
  2. Ability to test against different linux distributions
  3. Ability to run (at least some of) the E2E tests locally without relying on an ec2 instance - for quicker feedback loops when developing new features
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will remove the use of `peter-evans/slash-command-dispatch@v2` and transition to automatically running E2E tests on all pull requests, without requiring maintainer intervention.

Since Zarf v0.15 no longer requires registry1 credentials to build the initialization package or run core E2E tests, repository secrets are no longer needed for the majority of our test workflows. This eliminates the security risk that previously necessitated manual trigger approval via slash commands.

As part of this change, we will:

1. Update GitHub Actions workflows to run E2E tests automatically on `pull_request` events.
2. Maintain a subset of sensitive, secret-dependent tests (if any) in a separate workflow that remains manually triggered via maintainers-only permissions.
3. Begin incremental improvements to support testing across:
   - Multiple Kubernetes distributions (e.g., K3s, Kind, Minikube)
   - Multiple Linux distributions (e.g., Ubuntu, Amazon Linux, CentOS) via matrix testing where appropriate
4. Refactor E2E test structure to improve local execution capability, enabling developers to run a representative subset of tests using local clusters and tooling without dependency on EC2 instances.

This shift improves developer experience, accelerates feedback loops, increases transparency, and aligns with open-source best practices while maintaining security.
predicted_decision:
## Decision

The previous E2E test code was not extensible enough to be reused to test Zarf against different kubernetes distributions. The test suite was refactored so that we could write a setup and teardown function for each kubernetes distribution we wanted to verify against and the test suite was then responsible for cycling through the different distributions. This gives us the ability to test multiple kubernetes distributions against the same exact test cases.

The individual test cases were also rewritten to not rely on terratest running a bash command over ssh. Instead, the test uses the locally built Zarf binary and example packages to validate expected behavior. This approach works both on local dev machines (linux/mac) and on the Ubuntu GitHub Runner that gets triggered when a pull request is created. This also has the positive side effect of not needing to wait several minutes for an ec2 instance to spin up for testing.

Since we no longer need repository secrets to run the E2E tests, we removed the requirement for a maintainer to use a `/test all` chatops command to dispatch the tests. Instead, there is a new test workflow defined for each kubernetes distribution we are verifying against and the tests get run automatically whenever a PR is created or updated.

When looking back at the list of 'important additions' we were considering above. All three are addressed with this approach. Testing against different kubernetes distributions is as simple as defining how to create and destroy the cluster. All of the test cases are runnable locally and then because of that testing on a linux distribution is possible by just switching over to another machine and running the same `make test-e2e` there. This also gives us the ability to test against cloud distributions like EKS! All you need is a valid kubeconfig and running `go test ./...` in the `./src/test/e2e` directory will run all of the test cases against the EKS cluster.

context:
## Context

In order to create any workloads in K8s, an image has to exist on the node or be pulled in from an OCI Distribution server (docker registry). Local K8s distros such as KIND, K3D, K3S, Microk8s have CLI support for injecting or pushing images into the CRIs of cluster nodes. No standard or tool exists to do this generically in K8s as the CRI sits outside the problem of K8s beyond just communicating with it. For Zarf to push images into a K8s cluster that does not have a CLI option to inject the image, we have to establish some mechanism to create a temporary registry, use an existing one, or inject the image in the cluster. Zarf must also support unknown environments with no other dependencies; we cannot assume a registry exists. Typically when K8s pulls images from a remote registry, it sends the request to the CRI that then does the pull outside of the K8s context. The CRI runs at the host level on a per-node basis, so to access a private registry, the TLS trust needs to be modified on any host/node that would attempt to pull the image. The two primary ways to do this are modifying the node's root certificate authorities or the CRIs configuration if it has an option for TLS root CA. Lastly, as this is per node, all nodes in the cluster would need to be modified or some affinity/taint to force the pod to use a single node during bootstrapping.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will implement an ephemeral, in-cluster image registry as part of the Zarf agent during package deployment. This registry will be deployed as a temporary service within the target Kubernetes cluster and used exclusively for distributing OCI images contained in the Zarf package.

The workflow will be:
1. Before applying any manifests, Zarf deploys a minimal, secure container registry (e.g., using Docker Distribution or Harbor) into the cluster.
2. The registry is exposed via ClusterIP and accessible only within the cluster network.
3. Zarf pushes all required images from the package to this in-cluster registry.
4. Image references in deployment manifests are rewritten to point to the local registry service.
5. Workloads are deployed with image pull specs targeting the local registry.
6. After successful deployment, the temporary registry may be retained (for air-gapped environments) or removed based on user configuration.

This approach eliminates dependency on external registries, avoids node-level TLS trust modifications, supports multi-node clusters seamlessly, and ensures compatibility across diverse K8s environments—including those without CLI-based image loading support. It also aligns with Zarf’s goal of enabling self-contained, dependency-free deployments in isolated or restricted environments.
predicted_decision:
## Decision

Because we cannot require third-party dependencies, the requirement from some cloud-managed or distro-managed registry is not an option as not every K8s cluster will have that available.  Running an in-memory registry while zarf is performing `zarf init` was initially explored to resolve the external dependency issue.  However, this solution proved too complex when dealing with network traversal (especially behind NATs), firewall, and NACL rulesets.  Additionally, because of the complexities around TLS trust, the in-memory registry was not a viable solution.

After iterating on several solutions, including `kubectl cp`, `kubectl exec`, a busybox configmap injection that brought in netcat to stream files, and a few variations on those ideas, we found using only configmaps to be the most predictable method for injection. The challenge with this mode is that the ETCD limit is 1 MB total, with binary data base64-encoded leaving roughly 670 KBs of data per configmap, far too small to bring the registry tarball in a single configmap. So instead, we used a combination of a custom Rust binary compiled with MUSL to perform file concatenation, untarring, and verification of a set of split tarball chunks across a variable number of configmaps. We found that chunking by less than the near-maximum configmap size was more performant on some resource-constrained control planes. The details of this solution and a drawing are located in the main README of this repo.

## Context

SBOM are required for software running on government hardware per EO14028.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will generate a Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) for all software builds intended for deployment on government hardware, in compliance with Executive Order (EO) 14028.

The SBOM will be generated using the [Syft](https://github.com/anchore/syft) tool by Anchore, which supports comprehensive dependency enumeration and output formats including SPDX, CycloneDX, and Syft JSON. The preferred format for distribution and integration with government tooling will be **SPDX Tag-Value** due to its widespread adoption and compatibility with federal requirements.

SBOM generation will be integrated into the CI/CD pipeline:
- Automatically triggered on every build tagged for production or marked as a release candidate.
- Attached to the build artifacts and stored alongside them in the artifact repository.
- Signed using a cryptographic key tied to the build system to ensure integrity and provenance.

Additionally:
- The SBOM will include all direct and transitive dependencies, including operating system packages and language-level dependencies.
- For containerized deployments, the SBOM will be generated from the final container image.
- Processes will be established to provide SBOMs upon request for any released version.

This approach ensures compliance, improves supply chain transparency, and enables faster vulnerability response across deployments on government systems.

## Decision

Using Witness' Syft attestor functionality allows Zarf to continue to get more refined SBOM capabilities as Witness' capabilities expand over time. Syft is capable of finding installed packages and some binaries for statically compiled dependencies over each image within a Zarf package. This allows for SBOMs for each image to be generated and packaged along with the Zarf package.  Abilities to export the SBOM to SDPX and CycloneDX formatted documents as well as a browse-able web page are in works.

context:
## Context

Currently Zarf leverages [Helm Post Rendering](https://helm.sh/docs/topics/advanced/#post-rendering) to mutate image paths and secrets for K8s to use the internal [Zarf Registry](../packages/zarf-registry/). This works well for simple K8s deployments where Zarf is performing the actual manifest apply but fails when using a secondary gitops tools suchs as [Flux](https://github.com/fluxcd/flux2), [ArgoCD](https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/stable/), etc. At that point, Zarf is unable to provide mutation and it is dependent on the package author to do the mutations themselves using rudimentary templating. Further, this issue also exists when for CRDs that references the [git server](../packages/gitea/). A `zarf prepare` command was added previously to make this less painful, but it still requires additional burden on package authors to do something we are able to prescribe in code.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will introduce a new `mutators` field in the Zarf package definition that allows declarative specification of transformations to be applied to Kubernetes manifests at deploy time, regardless of whether Zarf applies the manifests directly or via a GitOps tool.

This `mutators` field will support common mutation patterns such as:
- Image path rewriting (e.g., redirecting to the internal Zarf Registry)
- Secret injection or reference updating
- Service endpoint modifications (e.g., for Gitea or other embedded services)

These mutators will be executed during the deployment phase, after manifest templating but before any apply operation—whether performed by Zarf or an external GitOps controller. When using GitOps tools like Flux or ArgoCD, Zarf will pre-process the manifests using the defined mutators and commit the transformed manifests into the target repository, ensuring the correct internal references are used.

This approach shifts the burden of manual mutation from the package author to the Zarf framework, providing reliable, consistent behavior across deployment strategies while maintaining compatibility with GitOps workflows.

The `zarf prepare` command will be deprecated in favor of this more robust and integrated solution.

## Context

In ADR 3, the decision was made to create a rust binary (`stage1`) that would re-assemble a `registry:2` image and a go registry binary (`stage2`) from a series of configmaps. While this solution works, it is overkill for the operations that `stage2` performs. The `stage2` binary is only responsible for 1. starting a docker registry in `rw` mode, 2. pushing the `registry:2` crane tarball into said registry, 3. starting the docker registry in `r` mode. This `registry:2` image is then immediately consumed by the `zarf-registry` package, creating a true in-cluster docker registry. The injector pod is then destroyed. The overhead this operation creates:

- having to keep track of another binary (making the total number 3 for the zarf ecosystem)
- nearly doubling the amount of configmaps loaded into the cluster (makes init slower)
- having to compile the binary for each platform (adds to the build time + ci)
- using a full-featured docker registry to host a single image (wasteful)
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

Replace the `stage2` Go binary with a minimal Rust binary that directly serves the `registry:2` image tarball using a lightweight HTTP server, conforming to the Docker Registry HTTP API v2 for a single-image use case.

This new binary will:
- Eliminate the need to run and manage a full Docker registry instance
- Reduce resource footprint and initialization time
- Remove cross-platform compilation overhead by integrating with existing Rust build pipeline
- Decrease the number of configmaps required by embedding or streaming the tarball more efficiently
- Be embedded within the same binary as `stage1` where possible to reduce binary count

The solution will maintain compatibility with the `zarf-registry` package's expectations by implementing just enough of the Docker Registry API to serve the single image.

- not only re-assemble + unpack the tarball, but also unpack the `registry:2` image (stored as a [crane tarball format](https://github.com/google/go-containerregistry/tree/main/pkg/v1/tarball))
- transform the `registry:2` crane manifest to a docker v2 manifest
- spin up an HTTP server compliant with the v2 docker registry API to serve the `registry:2` image

## Context

There are sections of the code that are not easily able to be tested by our end-to-end testing and now that Zarf is moving into being a library for other products there will be more scrutiny around our defined interfaces.  This ADR explores ways that we could adjust our testing strategy to address these concerns.

Potential considerations:

1. Introduce Unit-Testing Zarf-wide
    Pros:
        - More of the codebase is covered with tests and will force us to take more consideration when updating it
    Cons:
        - As the codebase evolves the efficacy of these tests is likely to go down, especially if they are written to the code rather than the interface

2. Introduce Unit Testing in a defined and limited capacity within Zarf
    Pros:
        - A decent amount of the codebase will be tested (specifically we can target those areas difficult to e2e test)
        - We can be picky about what/where we unit test so that the maintenance burden of the tests is not too high
    Cons:
        - We will need to be vigilant when PRs come through with Unit Tests that these are correct applications of them

3. Introduce Integration Testing or partial End-to-End testing
    Pros:
        - This is closer to how we already test within Zarf
    Cons:
        - These can be relatively complex to orchestrate and maintain over time requiring complex mocks or other mechanisms to make them work
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will adopt **Option 2: Introduce Unit Testing in a defined and limited capacity within Zarf**.

Unit tests will be introduced selectively to cover areas of the codebase that are:
- Difficult or impractical to test through end-to-end testing
- Stability-critical (e.g. package generation, image/manifest handling, configuration parsing)
- Well-defined in scope and interface-bound rather than implementation-bound

We will prioritize writing unit tests that validate public interfaces and exported functions, especially those intended for use by external consumers now that Zarf is evolving into a library. Tests should be focused on pure functions, data transformation logic, and error handling paths that do not require complex system setup.

To mitigate maintenance burden:
- A `TESTING.md` guide will be created to document when unit tests are appropriate vs. discouraged
- PR reviews will enforce that new unit tests align with the strategy (e.g. avoid over-mocking, prefer table-driven tests, focus on behavior not implementation)
- We will favor minimal mocking and instead use dependency injection where needed to isolate components

Integration and partial e2e tests will remain our primary validation mechanism for system-level behavior, while unit tests fill targeted gaps in coverage and increase confidence in library-style usage.

1. Is what I want to test a true unit (i.e. a single function or file)?
2. Does what I want to test have a clearly defined interface (i.e. a public specification)?

## Context

Images are not the only way that dependencies can be brought in via a Zarf package (our own init package has two components that are not images yet could have vulnerabilities within them, k3s and the injector).  We should SBOM these in addition to images so that we are providing a more complete picture to our users.

Potential considerations:

1. Run Syft against the entire zarf temp build directory
    Pros:
        - This would provide the most information for what _might_ be in a Zarf package
    Cons:
        - If git repos are brought in you could catch many index files that are actually not in the package but are dependencies of the repos leading to confusion

2. Run Syft against files and dataInjections
    Pros:
        - We know these files are actually inside of the package and won't just be noise
        - This is the most common two ways for people to include additional artifacts in packages (we use files in our own init package)
    Cons:
        - This is only a subset of what Zarf provides and someone could commit an artifact to a git repo for example

3. Allow user flexibility in what gets SBOMed
    Pros:
        - This provides the user the most flexibility
    Cons:
        - This could be complex to get right on implementation and if it were optional may be a forgotten feature by most users
decision:
## Decision  
## Decision

We will implement **Option 2: Run Syft against files and dataInjections**.

This approach strikes the right balance between completeness and accuracy by focusing on artifacts that are definitively included in the package. While it does not cover every possible vector (e.g., files embedded in git repos), it captures the most common and intentional methods of including non-image dependencies—specifically `files` and `dataInjections`—which are already used in our init package.

By avoiding scanning the entire build directory, we prevent noise from transient or irrelevant files (e.g., Git metadata, local build artifacts), which could mislead users about actual package contents. Additionally, this method aligns well with Zarf’s declarative packaging model, where explicit file inclusion is preferred.

Although Option 3 offers more flexibility, the added complexity and risk of inconsistent usage outweigh its benefits for now. We can revisit extensibility in the future once we have clearer user requirements.

Thus, running Syft only on declared `files` and `dataInjections` ensures a reliable, maintainable, and useful SBOM generation process that reflects real package contents without introducing confusion.

## Context

Zarf was rooted in the idea of declarative K8s deployments for disconnected environments. Many of the design decisions made in Zarf are based on this idea. However, in certain connected environments, Zarf can still be leveraged as a way to define declarative deployments and upgrades without the constraints of disconnected environments. To that end, providing a declarative way to deploy Zarf packages without the need for a Zarf init package would be useful in such environments.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will introduce a new `zarf.yaml` field called `initRequired` (default: `true`) that allows package authors to specify whether the Zarf init package is required for deployment. When set to `false`, the `zarf init` command will be skipped during `zarf deploy`, and the package will be deployed directly using the cluster configuration from the local kubeconfig.

This enables use of Zarf's declarative deployment and upgrade capabilities in connected environments without requiring airgap tooling or pre-pushed images. The following behaviors apply when `initRequired: false`:

- `zarf deploy` does not expect or require a Zarf-generated seed image.
- Images, manifests, and other resources are pulled directly from their upstream sources as defined in the package.
- Git repos and data URLs are fetched at deploy time.
- The Zarf agent still runs to inject variables and manage secrets unless explicitly disabled.
- The `zarf init` command remains available but is optional for these packages.

Package authors must ensure all referenced artifacts are accessible from the target cluster’s network when using `initRequired: false`. This mode is intended for development, CI/CD, or trusted connected environments where airgap constraints do not apply.

## Context

Originally, the `scripts` noun was added to components to allow us to move hard-coded init business logic out of the codebase and into the package system. At the time there was only a `before` and `after` section with simply an array entry per command. Later, `prepare` was added as a way to do something during `zarf package create`. As teams began to find new ways to use the capabilities, their limitations became more obvious.
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will expand and formalize the `scripts` functionality within components to provide greater flexibility, clarity, and lifecycle control. The updated `scripts` section will support the following well-defined phases:

- `before`: Executes prior to component deployment. Useful for pre-requisite checks or environment setup.
- `after`: Executes after component deployment. Ideal for post-deployment configuration or validation.
- `prepare`: Executes during `zarf package create`. Used to bundle assets or generate files that should be included in the package.
- `validate`: Runs during deployment to confirm the component’s requirements are met (e.g., connectivity, permissions).
- `onFailure`: Optional script that runs if any of the preceding scripts or the component itself fails.

Each script phase will support:
- Multiple commands expressed as a list.
- Inline scripts or references to external script files.
- Environment variable injection.
- Cross-platform compatibility hints (e.g., `shell: bash` or `shell: powershell`).

This change preserves backward compatibility while enabling advanced use cases through a consistent, documented interface. Documentation will be updated to include examples, execution order, and error handling behavior.

## Decision

The `scripts` section of the `zarf.yaml` will be replaced with a new `actions` section. The `actions` section will be a map of action names to a list of commands to run. `actions` will contain `action sets` that map to the following lifecycle events:

- `onCreate` - Runs during `zarf package create`
- `onDeploy` - Runs during `zarf package deploy`
- `onRemove` - Runs during `zarf package remove`

In addition to adding more lifecycle events, the `actions` section will also allow for more complex actions to be defined. New configurations include, setting the cmd directory, defining custom env variables, setting the number of retries, setting the max total seconds, muting the output, and [setting a variable](../docs/3-create-a-zarf-package/7-component-actions.md#creating-dynamic-variables-from-actions) to be used in other actions or components.

Further details can be found in the `component-actions` [component actions documentation](../docs/3-create-a-zarf-package/7-component-actions.md), [package create lifecycle documentation](../docs/3-create-a-zarf-package/5-package-create-lifecycle.md), [package deploy lifecycle documentation](../docs/4-deploy-a-zarf-package/1-package-deploy-lifecycle.md), and the [example package](../examples/component-actions/README.md).

context:
## Context

There has been a long-standing usability gap with Zarf when doing local development due to a lack of local image support. A solution was merged in, [#1173](https://github.com/defenseunicorns/zarf/pull/1173), and released in [v0.23.4](https://github.com/defenseunicorns/zarf/releases/tag/v0.23.4) to support this feature. Unfortunately, we didn't realize there is a [glaring issue](https://github.com/defenseunicorns/zarf/issues/1214) with the implementation that causes Zarf to crash when trying to load large images into the local docker daemon.  The docker daemon support in Crane is somewhat naive and can send a machine into an OOM condition due to how the tar stream is loaded into memory from the docker save action. Crane does have an option to avoid this issue, but at the cost of being much slower to load images from docker.

We did extensive investigation into various strategies of loading docker images from the daemon including: crane, skopeo, the docker go client and executing the docker cli directly with varying levels of success. Unfortunately, some of the methods that did work well were up to 3 times slower than the current implementation, though they avoided the OOM issue. Lastly, the docker daemon save operations directly still ended up being slower than crane and docker produced a legacy format that would cause issues with [future package schema changes](https://github.com/defenseunicorns/zarf/issues/1319) we are planning for oci imports.

|                                                    | **Docker** | **Crane** |
| -------------------------------------------------- | ---------- | --------- |
| Big Bang Core (cached)                             | 3m 1s      | 1m 58s    |
| Big Bang Core (cached + skip-sbom)                 | 1m 51s     | 56s       |
| 20 GB Single-Layer Image (local registry)          |            | 6m 14s    |
| 20 GB Single-Layer Image (local registry + cached) | 5m 2s      | 2m 10s    |
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will revert the local image support feature until a more robust solution can be implemented that avoids both the OOM condition and significant performance degradation. While this means temporarily losing a highly requested capability, maintaining system stability and performance is prioritized.

We will continue investigating alternative approaches, including:
- Using crane with the memory-safe option despite its performance cost, potentially behind a user flag for large images
- Implementing streaming tar handling to process images in chunks rather than loading entirely into memory
- Exploring hybrid approaches that use different tools based on image size or layer count
- Contributing improvements upstream to crane's docker daemon handling

Local image support will be reintroduced in a future release when a solution is found that meets both stability and performance requirements, with clear documentation about limitations and trade-offs.

## Decision

We had hoped to leverage docker caching and avoid crane caching more, but realized that caching was still occurring via Syft for SBOM. Additionally, the extremely-large, local-only image is actually the edge case here and we created a recommended workaround in the FAQs as well as an inline alert when a large docker image is detected. This restores behavior to what it was before the docker daemon support was added, but with the added benefit of being able to load images from the docker daemon when they are available locally.

context:
## Context

One primary application component that end users of Zarf are deploying is [Big Bang](https://repo1.dso.mil/big-bang/bigbang). The installation of Big Bang is complicated for several reasons:

- It requires Flux to be installed to deploy correctly due to the use of Flux CRDs.
- The [images](https://umbrella-bigbang-releases.s3-us-gov-west-1.amazonaws.com/umbrella/1.51.0/package-images.yaml) defined within Big Bang are normally a superset of the images needed for any individual deployment.
- All images that Big Bang might need takes 10s of gigabytes of storage to include in a Zarf package.
- The git repositories defined within Big Bang are normally a superset of the git repositories needed for any individual deployment.
- Injecting a `values.yaml` file into the [default deployment structure](https://repo1.dso.mil/big-bang/bigbang/-/blob/master/base/kustomization.yaml) is complicated and the discovery of which images are needed is a function of the values that are provided to the Big Bang chart
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

To support efficient and flexible deployment of Big Bang with Zarf, we will implement a **Big Bang Integration Pattern** that combines the following approaches:

- **Flux Pre-Requisite**: Require Flux to be pre-installed or deployed as part of the Zarf package initialization, ensuring CRDs are available before Big Bang components are applied.
  
- **Dynamic Image & Git Repository Inclusion**: Instead of bundling all possible Big Bang images and git repos, use Zarf's ability to define templated or conditional resources. Leverage `zarf.yaml` transformations and user-provided values to determine which images and repositories are actually required for a given deployment.

- **Values Injection via Kustomize Overlay**: Create a Zarf-managed overlay structure that injects user-defined `values.yaml` into the Big Bang Kustomization pipeline. This allows customization of Big Bang behavior while preserving upstream compatibility.

- **Image List Pruning Based on Values**: Implement tooling (potentially external to Zarf but used in package creation) that parses the provided `values.yaml` and determines the minimal set of required images and git repositories by analyzing enabled components and dependencies. This drastically reduces package size.

- **Documentation and Example Package**: Provide a reference Zarf package example and documentation that demonstrates how to construct a minimal, values-driven Big Bang deployment using this pattern.

This approach ensures that Big Bang can be deployed securely and efficiently in air-gapped environments using Zarf, without requiring massive, monolithic packages containing unused assets.

The code then includes only the git repositories and images needed for the configured packages, and does not include the git repositories and images for packages that would not be deployed.

The `bigbang` section will provide the following configurations for managing a big bang deployment:

- `version` - Identifies the particular version of Big Bang to deploy, which corresponds to git tags in the provided `repo`. See versions of Big Bang [here](https://repo1.dso.mil/big-bang/bigbang/-/releases).
- `repo` - Identifies the git repository Big Bang is hosted on. Defaults to https://repo1.dso.mil/big-bang/bigbang.git
- `valuesFiles` - list of local files that get passed to the Big Bang helm chart for deployment.
- `skipFlux` - boolean to determine if the flux installation for Big Bang should be skipped. Only set this to true if flux has been deployed in a different way already in the cluster.

## Context

Zarf packages are currently only available if built locally or through manual file transfers. This is not a scalable way to distribute packages. We wanted to find a way to distribute and publish packages in a way that is easily consumable for the majority of users. When considering the goal of being able to share packages, security and trust are very important considerations. We wanted our publishing solution and architecture changes to keep in mind signing of packages and the ability to verify the integrity of packages.

We know we are successful when:

1. (Priority) Users can use Zarf to natively publish a Zarf package to an OCI compliant registry
2. (Secondary goal) Package creators can sign Zarf packages to enable package deployers can trust a packages supply chain security
decision:
## Decision 
## Decision

We will integrate Zarf with OCI (Open Container Initiative) registries to enable native publishing and distribution of Zarf packages. This allows users to push and pull Zarf packages just like container images, leveraging existing, widely adopted infrastructure.

To support supply chain security and trust:
- Zarf packages will be signed using cryptographic signatures at publish time.
- Package signatures will follow industry standards (e.g., Cosign or Sigstore) to allow verification upon deployment.
- Zarf will verify package integrity and signature authenticity by default before deploying a package from a registry.

This approach meets the primary goal of scalable, standardized distribution via OCI registries, and the secondary goal of enabling verifiable, secure software supply chains.
